item.title: The Major Economies’ Prospects in 2026
item.description: Political leaders tend to claim credit when the economy performs well and to pursue frantic reforms when it does not. But short-term policy measures will have little impact on the forces shaping the prospects of the world’s major economies today.

item.title: Trump’s Hobbesian World Order
item.description: With its Venezuela operation, the US has effectively given China an open invitation to invade Taiwan, vindicated Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and set the stage for more illegal US military actions. Large and rising powers – such as Germany, India, and Japan – must work together to affirm and enforce rules of conduct.

item.title: Trump’s Jungle Rules
item.description: The nature of US foreign policy under the current administration is now clear. America will unilaterally exercise power wherever Donald Trump thinks he can get away with it, uncoupled from the norms, bureaucratic processes, alliance structures, and multilateral institutions that once gave American leadership legitimacy.

item.title: Venezuela and the Future of the West
item.description: With 2026 barely underway, Donald Trump has pulled the rug out from under anyone who still believed in the salvageability of the old international order. The midnight US raid to capture Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, confirms that we are in a new era, and the question now is how the rest of the world will respond.

item.title: The Limits of Prediction Markets
item.description: The question of which bets on Time’s 2025 Person of the Year should pay out ignited furor on Kalshi and Polymarket, two major prediction markets. By reaching diametrically opposed conclusions, these platforms underscored the indispensable role of human interpretation in settling event contracts, despite claims of automation.

item.title: Overcapacity Is China’s Biggest AI Advantage
item.description: The global AI race will be won not by the power of models and chips, but by how effectively systems can be deployed and improved across the economy. China’s chronic excess capacity, long seen as its greatest weakness, has reduced costs and accelerated adoption, providing the country's AI sector with a decisive edge.

item.title: The Looming Population Bust
item.description: Across much of the world, fertility rates are falling and populations are aging faster than economies can adapt, putting pressure on labor markets, pension systems, and public finances. The challenge is made more difficult to address by growing resistance from older voters and risk-averse leaders.

item.title: The Hollowing Out of East Asian Industry
item.description: China’s changing economic structure, together with high and unpredictable US tariffs, has placed Japan and South Korea under intensifying pressure. Only by deepening engagement with each other, and with other reliable partners, can these countries safeguard the industries on which their economies depend.

item.title: The End of China’s One-Child Policy, Ten Years Later
item.description: The logic behind China’s family-planning policies was always suspect, as were the data that convinced officials to keep them in place long after it should have been clear that they had failed. The history of the 35-year one-child policy highlights a fatal flaw in Chinese governance, for which the country is paying a steep price.

item.title: Ensuring Pandemic Financing for Middle-Income Countries
item.description: During the COVID-19 pandemic, middle-income countries struggled to invest in vaccines and other medical countermeasures. To avoid repeating the same mistake, policymakers from these countries must demand that multilateral development banks make at-risk financing available as soon as the next outbreak occurs.

item.title: Europe Does Not Lack Capital - It Lacks Scale
item.description: Even the best startups cannot thrive sustainably in an environment where each country protects its national champions, and where administrative barriers prevent the emergence of truly European ones. If Europe wants to be a technological power, it must finally implement a genuine single market.

item.title: Does Venezuela Herald a No-Rules International Order?
item.description: The US intervention in Venezuela raises many questions, not just about its legality, but about the international order that the United States has long anchored. Although that order will not suddenly collapse, it will now be costlier and more difficult to sustain.

item.title: The Global Economic Transformation Will Be Local
item.description: Whether it is generating good jobs, navigating the climate transition, stimulating innovation, or building economic resilience, structural transformation is now the name of the game worldwide. While the ends may differ, the means are the same: effective state action, led by subnational governments.

item.title: The Ocean Has Finally Entered the Global Climate Debate
item.description: The world has started to recognize that the climate’s fate depends on what happens to the ocean. At COP30, ocean-based solutions attracted significant attention and investment, but much more must be done to establish the governance structures required for safeguarding this critical planetary system.

item.title: Will Japan Be the World’s Next AI Leader?
item.description: Japan has so far taken an “innovation-first” approach to AI governance, avoiding stringent rules or penalties that could stifle adoption or experimentation. Firms must make the most of this supportive environment to build the tools that can help offset the economic effects of population aging.

item.title: The Precedents to Trump’s Venezuela Operation
item.description: In ousting and arresting Nicolás Maduro, US President Donald Trump wants the political gains of fighting a war without actually having to fight one. Whereas fascists and imperialists know that war requires real combat, Trump seems unwilling or unable to go that far, not least because he is weak at home.

item.title: Trump’s Special Military Operation in Venezuela
item.description: The framers of the US Constitution designed a system to compel the executive to explain its actions, wagering that requiring justifications would discipline power and prevent its arbitrary exercise. President Donald Trump has called that bet – and won.

item.title: How the Stock Market Could Sink Trump in 2026
item.description: By emphasizing how well the US stock market is doing, US President Donald Trump could be setting himself up for electoral disappointment this November. With equities priced for perfection, any number of risks could deflate today's exuberance.

item.title: Trump’s Fear and Loathing of Europe
item.description: Just as some early-20th-century German nationalists viewed Russia as a useful ally against more liberal European countries and the "racially chaotic" United States, the US under Donald Trump regards Russia and Hungary as friends united against a common enemy: Europe. There are several reasons for this reversal.

item.title: The Trump Doctrine in Venezuela
item.description: The US military operation to arrest Nicolás Maduro underscores President Donald Trump’s view of the Western Hemisphere as a region where US interests take precedence. Russia and China will welcome this as a sign that Trump shares their vision of a world divided into spheres of influence.
